# 2024 Delaware Solar Incentives, Grants, Rebates, and Tax Credits

Updated to include 2024 Delaware solar incentives, rebates, and tax credits. Cash in on big savings to help offset the cost of solar panel installation in Delaware.

## What local Delaware solar incentives are available?

Delaware is committed to helping its residents make the switch to renewable energy. Below are some of the best Delaware solar incentives you can take advantage of.

[Image 7: Get a Free Delaware Solar Panel Estimate][Image 8: Get a Free Delaware Solar Panel Estimate]

## Get a Free Delaware Solar Panel Estimate

Requesting an estimate is 100% FREE and takes less than 5 minutes.

【44† Get your FREE estimate 】 

### Delaware Green Energy Program

The Delaware Green Energy Program, sponsored by the DE Energy Office, is a three-part state grant for those who use Delmarva Power & Light (DPL), Delaware Electric Cooperative (DEC), or state municipal utilities. 

【45†Delmarva Power & Light (DPL)†programs.dsireusa.org】 offers a maximum $6,000 rebate for solar panel installation. As more people take advantage, the maximum rebate amount has the potential to drop, so keep that in mind when exploring your options. 

【46†The Delaware Electric Cooperative†programs.dsireusa.org】 (DEC) offers $0.50 for the first 5kW and $0.20 after 5kW. The DEC also offers a 20% rebate on solar thermal and fuel cell installation costs.  

【47†The Delaware Municipal Electrical Corporation (DEMEC)†programs.dsireusa.org】 offers solar incentives only to the residents of Newark, DE and is valued at $1.00/W for the first 5 kW and $0.50/W after 5 kW.

## Net Metering in Delaware

【48†Net metering†v】 is another Delaware solar incentive. Home and business owners get financial credit applied to their electric bills when they produce excess solar energy. Credits generated during the summer can be used to offset the cost of winter electric bills. 

## Delaware Solar Renewable Energy Certificates (SRECs)

In addition to net metering, the  【49†Delaware SREC program†srecdelaware.com】 enables residents who own solar panel systems to earn money by selling excess power they generate back to the grid. At Solar Energy World, we calculate how much excess energy you are likely to generate from your solar panel installation, and we will set up the automatic system to earn and sell your SRECs.

## Federal Tax Credits for Delaware Residents

You don’t have to limit yourself to local or state incentives. You can also take part in a federal program through the 【50†Investment Tax Credit (ITC)†www.energy.gov】. You can qualify for this credit as a homeowner if you purchase your PV system fully with cash or through a solar loan. You claim the credit when you file your federal taxes for the year. This credit covers 30 percent of your system costs. You can see this is a good year to add solar because federal tax credits are available and they provide a huge deduction.

Interested in solar panel installation for your home? We can help you take advantage of any applicable Delaware solar incentives available to you. Solar Energy World has years of experience providing 【12†Delaware solar panel installation services】 to local homeowners.

content.text:
A tax credit is a dollar-for-dollar reduction in the amount of federal taxes owed. The ITC lets you reduce your federal taxes by an amount equal to a certain percentage of your cost to purchase a solar system. Homeowners and businesses are eligible for the ITC only if they own the solar system. Owners of solar projects that are completed from 2022 through 2032 are eligible to deduct from their federal taxes 30% of the cost of their solar project. That percentage drops to 26% in 2033, then 22% in 2034, and disappears in 2035. So if you purchased a solar project that cost $25,000 and was installed on your house or business in 2022, you can deduct 30% of that, or $7,500, from your 2022 federal taxes. If your total federal tax owed is less than $7,500, your federal taxes would be $0 and the rest would carry forward to a later tax year.

The following solar costs are covered by the ITC:

  * Solar panel cost
  * Labor cost including installation, permitting fees, inspection fees, and developer fees
  * All other solar equipment costs (including batteries charged by solar)
  * Sales taxes on eligible equipment

The above information is not professional tax advice or guidance. For information on how to claim the ITC and how it applies to your specific situation we recommend contacting a tax professional.

## Inflation Reduction Act:

Learn how the Inflation Reduction Act can help homeowners, businesses or manufacturers in the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) Solar Energy Technologies Office resources.

【33†Homeowners Guide to Federal Tax Credit for Solar Photovoltaics †www.energy.gov】

【34†Federal Solar Tax Credit for Businesses†www.energy.gov】

【35†Federal Solar Tax Credit for Manufacturers†www.energy.gov】

## Financing:

Financing for solar systems is available through Energize Delaware’s programs for residents, businesses and nonprofits.

  * Energize Delaware Residential Solar Loan Program: The Energize Delaware Solar Loan program, administered by the Delaware Sustainable Energy Utility, offers a low interest solar loan designed to encourage the purchase of customer sited and owned solar systems. The loan amount for the program ranges from $5,000-$30,000, with the total loan amount not exceeding 70% of the total project cost. The term of the loan is 10 years, and the interest rate is 3.9%. For more information about the loan and the eligibility requirements, please visit the 【36†program homepage. †energizedelawareloans.org】

  * Energize Delaware Low-Interest Commercial Loan Program: Energize Delaware has a special low interest loan program for small to mid-sized businesses. Program financing is available to all credit-qualified businesses located in existing facilities, whether owned or leased, in the State of Delaware. Loan amounts can range between $30,000 and $2,000,000 per project for businesses and are based on availability of funds. No more than $2,000,000 shall be outstanding to any one borrower. For additional information and eligibility requirements visit the 【37†program page†www.energizedelaware.org】.
  * Energize Delaware Performance Contracting Program: The Performance Contracting Program is for schools, universities, municipalities, hospitals, privately held institutions and nonprofit organizations. It uses long term utility cost savings derived from implemented projects to fund the improvements and is delivered through a group of prequalified Energy Services Companies (ESCO’s). For more information on this program, please visit the 【38†program’s website†www.energizedelaware.org】.
  * C-PACE: Commercial property assessed clean energy, or C-PACE, is an energy efficiency financing program that has been adopted by more than 30 states, including Delaware. The program allows commercial entities to secure financing to make sustainable improvements to their properties, including the installation of a solar system. The financing is provided by capital providers in an open market, which provides property owners with competitive, private financing. Because the long-term financing can cover up to 100 percent of a building’s modernization project cost and often requires no money down, C-PACE enables property owners to make substantial upgrades to their buildings. For more information on the C-PACE program, please visit the 【39†program’s website. †www.delawarecpace.org】

## Utilities & State Incentive Programs 

### Delmarva Power & Light (DPL):

  * Green Energy Program: Delmarva Power customers can apply for a solar grant through the Green Energy Program, administered by the Delaware Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Control, or DNREC. The Green Energy Program has provided grant funding to more than 4,300 Delaware renewable energy projects since 1999. Grant applications must be submitted through the 【40†Green Grant Delaware†greengrantdelaware.com】 online application system.  
To qualify for the Green Energy Program grant, the solar system must be installed by an 【41†approved renewable energy contractor†dnrec.alpha.delaware.gov】. DNREC has published 【42†instructions for applying†documents.dnrec.delaware.gov】 to the Green Energy Program as well as the 【43†current incentive rates†documents.dnrec.delaware.gov】.

  * Low- to Moderate-Income Solar Pilot Program (LMI): The two-year LMI Solar Pilot Program, administered by DNREC, utilizes Delmarva Power funds to promote the use of renewable energy in low- and moderate-income households in Delmarva Power territory. # Energize Delaware for Businesses

As Delaware’s  resource for saving money, creating jobs and improving the environment, Energize Delaware offers new ways for commercial, industrial, service, retail and other businesses to take charge of their energy future.

We know you’re willing to do your part by using less energy and protecting the environment. We’re doing our part too, by getting your business on the path to energy efficiency through available revolving loans, multifamily housing energy grants, geothermal grants, solar grants and much more.

Explore our many options below for reducing your energy use, electric bills and environmental impacts of energy production, delivery and use.

## Energize Delaware Programs

【57† †www.delawarecpace.org】 【57†Delaware Property Assessed Clean Energy (D-PACE) †www.delawarecpace.org】 

D-PACE is designed to help qualifying commercial, industrial, agricultural, nonprofit and multifamily (with five or more units) property owners access long term financing for the installation of qualifying energy improvements. Such improvements may include any construction, renovation or retrofitting of energy efficient technology, clean energy systems, or qualifying waste heat recovery technologies that are permanently fixed to qualifying commercial property. 

【47† 】 【47†Low Interest Commercial Loan Program 】 

With this program, businesses can borrow from $10,000 up to $2,000,000 per project, with attractive terms and interest rates for energy efficiency measures and renewable energy initiatives. 

【58† 】 【58†Business Technical Assistance 】 

This program is designed to provide small and mid-size commercial building owners and contractors, at no-cost, the technical assistance needed to maximize energy efficiency and access 100% long-term financing for improvements like HVAC replacement, LED lighting and solar PV installations. 

【34† 】 【34†Affordable Multifamily Housing 】 

This program provides multifamily building owners with technical assistance, financial incentives and low-cost financing for energy efficiency upgrades and renewable energy investments to reduce building operating costs. 

【35† 】 【35†Solar Renewable Energy Credits 】 

Commercial businesses with solar electricity can earn extra income by selling their excess energy back to Delmarva Power through the SREC (Solar Renewable Certificates) Energy Auction. 

## Other Programs

【36† 】 【36†Energy Efficiency Investment Fund for Business 】 

This fund provides prescriptive incentives to help commercial businesses install high-efficiency natural gas heating and water heating equipment, lighting and controls, vending improvements, and more. 

【37† 】 【37†Green Energy Program 】 

This program offers businesses and organizations grants to offset the installed costs of photovoltaic, solar water heating, wind and geothermal renewable energy technologies for customers of certain utilities. 

【38† 】 【38†Commercial Energy Assessments 】 

The first step for businesses to learn where their energy efficiencies can be improved is the Commercial Grade Energy Audit. It’s a professional evaluation that reports on all of your heating, cooling and electrical systems, from which, smart recommendations on energy upgrades can be made.

# Solar Renewable Energy Credits (SREC)

In Delaware, the Renewable Portfolio Standard (RPS) requires electricity suppliers to secure a portion of their electricity from solar generators.  To comply with the RPS, Delmarva must purchase Solar Renewable Energy Credits (SRECs) each year.

SRECs are credits generated by a solar system based on the electricity produced by the system. One SREC is generated for every megawatt hour (MWh), or 1,000 kilowatt hours (kWh), of electricity generated by a solar system. SRECs represent the “green” and renewable value of the electricity generated by a solar system. It is important to note that SRECs are sold separately from the electricity a system produces.

The value of an SREC is determined by the market subject to supply and demand constraints. SRECs can be sold to electricity suppliers needing to meet their solar RPS requirement.

The DESEU supports the RPS standard and therefore supports the SREC market with programs.

## Annual SREC Procurement Program

In 2011, the Delaware legislature amended the solar portion of the state Renewable Portfolio Standard (RPS) to switch the burden of acquiring SRECs away from the power providers to the electric distribution companies in Delaware. This amendment drastically reduced the number of buyer participants, effectively making Delmarva Power, the largest electric distribution utility in Delaware, the de-facto long term buyer for the majority of the DE SREC requirement. In response, Delmarva Power proposed the implementation of an SREC procurement program, called the SREC Delaware Procurement Program that provides long-term contracts to SREC sellers on a competitive basis.

Delmarva, which has selected the DESEU to operate the program, plans to run at least one solicitation each year in order to fulfill its long-term SREC needs.

The SREC Delaware Program holds an annual procurement for customers who what to participate in the Program. Each procurement is unique and divides solar properties into tiers based on their attributes, such as system size, interconnection date, and ownership type. Each procurement is bid-based — meaning that the lowest bids are accepted in each tier.

During each procurement there is a two-week window when applicants can submit bids. Each bid includes information about the system, and the price that the applicant would be willing to accept per SREC. At the end of the two-week window, the Program Administrator verifies that each bid is valid. All valid bids are ordered from lowest price to highest price, and the lowest price bids are accepted until the given tier is full. Winning bids are awarded a multi-year contract to sell their SRECs under the program.

Solar properties that have been built with either Delaware labor or Delaware manufactured parts may be granted an SREC bonus of 10% for each qualification. For example, a property that qualifies as having been built with Delaware labor may be granted the equivalent of 10% SREC bonus for every SREC produced. A property that is certified as having been built with both DE parts and labor is qualified for a 20% bonus for every SREC produced, etc. The Delaware Public Service Commission will certify that a property meets the qualifications for each bonus.

content.title: Solar Renewable Energy Credits - Energize Delaware

parts:
Delaware offers a variety of programs and incentives to support commercial solar installations. Here are some key programs available:

1. **Green Energy Program**: This program is administered by the Delaware Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Control (DNREC) and offers grants to businesses and organizations to offset the installed costs of photovoltaic (PV) systems. Customers of Delmarva Power & Light, Delaware Electric Cooperative, and Delaware Municipal Electrical Corporation can apply for these grants【6†source】【7†source】.

2. **Solar Renewable Energy Credits (SRECs)**: SRECs are credits generated by solar systems based on their electricity production. Businesses can sell these credits to electricity suppliers to meet the state’s Renewable Portfolio Standard (RPS) requirements. Delmarva Power runs an annual SREC procurement program to facilitate this process【9†source】【10†source】.

3. **Delaware Property Assessed Clean Energy (D-PACE) Program**: This program provides long-term financing for energy efficiency and renewable energy improvements. It allows commercial property owners to finance solar installations and repay the cost through a voluntary assessment on their property tax bill【8†source】【9†source】.

4. **Low-Interest Commercial Loan Program**: Administered by Energize Delaware, this program offers loans ranging from $30,000 to $2,000,000 for energy efficiency and renewable energy projects. The program aims to make it easier for businesses to invest in solar energy by providing attractive terms and interest rates【7†source】【9†source】.

5. **Federal Investment Tax Credit (ITC)**: Businesses can also take advantage of the federal ITC, which allows them to deduct 30% of the cost of installing a solar energy system from their federal taxes. This incentive is available for systems installed through 2032, with the percentage decreasing gradually after that【7†source】.

These programs collectively help reduce the upfront costs of solar installations, provide long-term financial benefits, and support Delaware’s goal of increasing renewable energy use.

For more detailed information and application processes, you can visit the [Energize Delaware website](https://www.energizedelaware.org) and the [Delaware Green Energy Program page](https://www.dnrec.delaware.gov).
can you run a 10 year pro-forma for a 300 kW system with a $600,000 price

content.text:
import pandas as pd

# Parameters for the pro-forma
system_size_kW = 300
system_cost = 600000
annual_production_per_kW = 1350  # in kWh (average for mid-Atlantic region)
electricity_rate_per_kWh = 0.1  # in dollars
annual_degradation_rate = 0.005  # 0.5% annual degradation
srec_price_per_mWh = 50  # in dollars per MWh (average)
annual_inflation_rate = 0.02  # 2% annual increase in electricity price

# Federal Investment Tax Credit (ITC)
itc_rate = 0.3  # 30%

# Initial calculations
first_year_production_kWh = system_size_kW * annual_production_per_kW
first_year_revenue_from_electricity = first_year_production_kWh * electricity_rate_per_kWh
first_year_revenue_from_srecs = (first_year_production_kWh / 1000) * srec_price_per_mWh

# Create DataFrame for pro-forma
years = range(1, 11)
data = {
    "Year": years,
    "Annual Production (kWh)": [],
    "Revenue from Electricity ($)": [],
    "Revenue from SRECs ($)": [],
    "Total Revenue ($)": [],
}

for year in years:
    annual_production = first_year_production_kWh * ((1 - annual_degradation_rate) ** (year - 1))
    revenue_from_electricity = annual_production * (electricity_rate_per_kWh * ((1 + annual_inflation_rate) ** (year - 1)))
    revenue_from_srecs = (annual_production / 1000) * srec_price_per_mWh
    total_revenue = revenue_from_electricity + revenue_from_srecs
    
    data["Annual Production (kWh)"].append(annual_production)
    data["Revenue from Electricity ($)"].append(revenue_from_electricity)
    data["Revenue from SRECs ($)"].append(revenue_from_srecs)
    data["Total Revenue ($)"].append(total_revenue)

# ITC benefit
itc_benefit = system_cost * itc_rate

# Create DataFrame
df = pd.DataFrame(data)

# Calculate cumulative revenue and payback period
df["Cumulative Revenue ($)"] = df["Total Revenue ($)"].cumsum()
df["Payback Period (Years)"] = df["Cumulative Revenue ($)"].apply(lambda x: x if x < system_cost - itc_benefit else system_cost - itc_benefit)

import ace_tools as tools; tools.display_dataframe_to_user(name="10-Year Pro-Forma for 300 kW Solar System", dataframe=df)

df

- **First Year Revenue from SRECs**: $20,250

The system is expected to generate cumulative revenue that covers the initial investment cost within approximately 6-7 years, considering the ITC benefit. The annual degradation rate, annual production, and cumulative revenue are also detailed in the pro-forma.

can you explain how the SREC program works

The Solar Renewable Energy Certificates (SREC) program is a market-based instrument that provides financial incentives for the generation of renewable energy, particularly solar power. Here’s a detailed explanation of how the SREC program works:

### How SRECs are Created
1. **Generation**: When a solar energy system generates electricity, it produces SRECs based on the amount of electricity generated. Typically, one SREC is equivalent to one megawatt-hour (MWh) of electricity (1,000 kilowatt-hours (kWh)).

### SREC Markets and Sales
2. **Market Value**: The value of an SREC is determined by market demand and supply, which can fluctuate. Prices can be influenced by state regulations, the overall demand for renewable energy, and the number of SRECs available in the market.
3. **Trading**: SRECs can be sold or traded in an open market. System owners can sell their SRECs directly to utilities, brokers, or through SREC marketplaces. In some states, utilities are required to purchase a certain number of SRECs to comply with state renewable portfolio standards (RPS).

### SREC Procurement Programs
4. **Procurement Programs**: Some states or utilities run SREC procurement programs, where they purchase SRECs through competitive bidding processes. For example, in Delaware, Delmarva Power operates an annual SREC procurement program where they solicit bids from SREC sellers and award long-term contracts to the lowest bidders.

### Compliance and Reporting
5. **Compliance**: Utilities and energy suppliers use SRECs to meet the requirements set by the state’s RPS. RPS mandates that a certain percentage of the electricity sold by these entities must come from renewable sources. By purchasing SRECs, utilities can demonstrate compliance with these mandates.
6. **Reporting**: Solar system owners or aggregators report the amount of electricity generated to a tracking system that issues SRECs based on verified production data.

### Benefits for Solar System Owners
7. **Revenue Stream**: Selling SRECs provides an additional revenue stream for solar system owners, helping to offset the initial cost of installing solar panels. This can significantly improve the return on investment for solar projects.
8. **Encouraging Solar Adoption**: The financial incentive provided by SRECs encourages more individuals and businesses to invest in solar energy, contributing to the growth of renewable energy capacity.

### Delaware Specifics
- **Annual Procurement**: Delmarva Power, in collaboration with the Delaware Sustainable Energy Utility (DESEU), conducts an annual procurement program to purchase SRECs. Solar system owners submit bids, and the lowest bids are accepted until the procurement goals are met.
- **SREC Bonuses**: In Delaware, additional bonuses can be awarded if the solar system uses Delaware-manufactured parts or is installed using Delaware labor.

Overall, the SREC program is a key mechanism in promoting the adoption of solar energy by providing financial incentives to solar system owners, thereby supporting state renewable energy goals and reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

content.text:
# Project future SREC prices using a simple linear regression for demonstration purposes

import numpy as np
from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression

# Preparing the data for linear regression
X = np.array(years).reshape(-1, 1)
y = np.array(prices)

# Creating the model and fitting it
model = LinearRegression()
model.fit(X, y)

# Projecting prices for the next 5 years
future_years = np.array(range(2024, 2029)).reshape(-1, 1)
future_prices = model.predict(future_years)

# Adding projected prices to the DataFrame
projected_years = list(range(2024, 2029))
projected_prices_df = pd.DataFrame({
    'Year': projected_years,
    'SREC Price ($)': future_prices
})

# Combining historical and projected data
combined_df = pd.concat([historical_prices_df, projected_prices_df])

# Plotting the combined historical and projected SREC prices
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
plt.plot(combined_df['Year'], combined_df['SREC Price ($)'], marker='o', linestyle='-', label='Historical Prices')
plt.plot(projected_years, future_prices, marker='o', linestyle='--', label='Projected Prices', color='orange')
plt.title('Historical and Projected SREC Prices')
plt.xlabel('Year')
plt.ylabel('SREC Price ($)')
plt.legend()
plt.grid(True)
plt.xticks(list(range(2014, 2029)))
plt.show()

import ace_tools as tools; tools.display_dataframe_to_user(name="Historical and Projected SREC Prices", dataframe=combined_df)

combined_df

Delaware’s renewable energy portfolio standards (RPS) are established by the Renewable Energy Portfolio Standards Act (【108†26 Del.C. § 351 – § 364†delcode.delaware.gov】), first adopted in 2005, and most recently amended by 【109†Senate Bill 33†legis.delaware.gov】, which was 【110†signed into law by Governor Carney†news.delaware.gov】 on Feb. 10, 2021.

The Act is intended to establish a market in Delaware for electricity from renewable sources and to lower the cost of renewable energy to consumers. The Act allows utilities to meet their portfolio standards by buying renewable energy credits (RECs) and solar renewable energy credits (SRECs) from wind, solar and other renewable sources.

The Act requires that Delmarva Power submit an annual report to the Public Service Commission showing compliance with the renewable energy portfolio standards. Their 【111†2015/2016 report†depsc.delaware.gov】 is posted on the Public Service Commission website.

### How to Sell Renewable Energy Credits

Sales of renewable energy credits are made under the 【105†Delaware Solar Renewable Energy Credits (SREC) Program†srecdelaware.com】. Each spring the SREC program releases an annual procurement program to accept bids for sales of credits.

Installed renewable energy systems must be certified by the 【112†Delaware Public Service Commission†depsc.delaware.gov】 (PSC) in order to sell renewable energy credits. Information on certification application, fees, and 【113†instructions for submission†depsc.delaware.gov】 can be found on the PSC’s 【114†Renewable Portfolio Standard and Green Power Products†depsc.delaware.gov】 page under the heading “RPS Forms.”

Once a system is certified, sellers set up accounts with the 【106†Generation Attribute Tracking System†www.pjm-eis.com】 (GATS) provided by PJM Environmental Information Services, Inc. This system is an online platform to connect renewable energy credit sellers and buyers and to track their transactions to help meet government standards.

For information about the current value of renewable energy credits or questions concerning how to trade your credits, please contact your installation contractor. There are links and resources on the PSC’s 【114†Renewable Portfolio Standards and Green Power Products†depsc.delaware.gov】 page. If you have questions regarding the Renewable Portfolio Standards, please contact Pamela Knotts (302.736.7500) and the Public Service Commission.

### The Old Cost Cap Provision

### 2016 Cost Cap Determination

【115†2016 Report to the Director†documents.dnrec.delaware.gov】 (【116†Appendices to the report†documents.dnrec.delaware.gov】)

【117†Director’s Preliminary Determination†documents.dnrec.delaware.gov】

【118†Public Comments†documents.dnrec.delaware.gov】

【119†Report on Public Comments†documents.dnrec.delaware.gov】

【120†Director’s Final Cost Cap Determination†documents.dnrec.delaware.gov】

The Renewable Energy Standards Portfolio Act included a cost cap provision (【121†26 Del. C. § 354(i) and (j)†delcode.delaware.gov】) that was stricken by 【109†Senate Bill 33†legis.delaware.gov】 and replaced by revisions to the system of alternate compliance payments (ACPs) and solar alternate compliance payments (SACPs), which set a maximum price for RECs and SRECs.

Regulation 2102 (【122†7 DE Admin Code 2102†regulations.delaware.gov】) governing this process was promulgated in 2016 and 【123†repealed effective August 11, 2017†regulations.delaware.gov】. Regulation 2102 was repealed to comply with a commitment to repeal the regulation made to Superior Court Judge Abigail LeGrow in the lawsuit DPA v. DNREC.

# Governor Carney Signs Legislation Raising Renewable Portfolio Standard (RPS)

【115†Governor John Carney】 | 【116†Office of the Governor】 | 【117†The Environment】 | Date Posted: Wednesday, February 10, 2021  

 【118† Listen †app-na.readspeaker.com】 

[Image 3]  

### Legislation sets target of 40 percent renewable energy by 2035

WILMINGTON, Del. – Governor John Carney on Wednesday signed 【119†Senate Bill 33†legis.delaware.gov】, raising Delaware’s Renewable Portfolio Standard (RPS) to 40 percent by 2035. 

【120†Click here to watch the virtual bill signing.†youtu.be】

The legislation – sponsored by Senator Stephanie Hansen and Representative Ed Osienski – will raise the percentage of Delaware’s energy that must come from renewable sources through 2035 and help confront the impacts of climate change. Increasing the Renewable Portfolio Standard also was a longtime priority of former Senator Harris McDowell. 

> “Delaware is the country’s lowest-lying state, and climate change is already having a very real impact,” said Governor Carney. “This legislation will help accelerate Delaware’s transition to renewable sources of energy,
content.title: Governor Carney Signs Legislation Raising Renewable Portfolio Standard (RPS) - State of Delaware News

content.text:
“Companies’ practices have taken a heavy toll on our environment for far too long. Especially here in low-lying Delaware, where sea-level rise is a top concern, it’s critical we take action to protect our natural resources and prevent further ecological damage,” said Rep. Osienski, D-Brookside, the lead House sponsor. “Renewable energy portfolio standards have proven to be an effective solution to transitioning away from harmful fossil fuels toward clean, green energy like solar, wind and geothermal. Because we’re on-target to hit 25% by 2025, it makes good sense to establish new goals for our RPS program.”

Under SB 33, which passed the House 29-12, the percentage of renewable energy from solar photovoltaics also would nearly triple from a target of 3.5% by 2025 to 10% by 2035.

“Climate change is the key issue of our time and we will be judged based on our collective action or inaction,” said Senator Stephanie Hansen, D-Middletown, the lead sponsor of SB 31. “By taking proactive steps to raise our renewable portfolio standard, we can simultaneously reduce our carbon footprint, spur innovation and job growth, and position our state for an affordable, efficient clean energy future. I am proud that we managed to pass this legislation in short order this year and look forward to building on this progress throughout the 151st General Assembly.”

The bill also would settle a dispute over cost caps for renewable energy credits (RECs) by establishing a maximum price and alternative compliance payments, should the cost of these credits rise unexpectedly. This market-based mechanism would replace the existing cost cap provisions, aims to end ongoing litigation on the subject, and protects ratepayers.

SB 33 now goes to Governor John Carney for his signature.

parts:
Delaware's Renewable Portfolio Standard (RPS) has seen recent legislative changes aimed at significantly increasing the state's use of renewable energy. As of the latest updates, Delaware's RPS mandates that 40% of the state's electricity must come from renewable sources by 2035. This includes a specific target for solar energy, which must constitute 10% of the state's energy mix by the same year.

The most recent change was made with Senate Bill 33, signed into law by Governor John Carney. This legislation not only increases the overall renewable energy target but also aims to nearly triple the proportion of solar energy from 3.5% by 2025 to 10% by 2035. This ambitious goal is part of Delaware's broader strategy to combat climate change and reduce its carbon footprint.

Additionally, the bill includes provisions to address cost caps for renewable energy credits (RECs) and solar renewable energy credits (SRECs). It establishes a market-based mechanism for alternative compliance payments to manage the cost of these credits, ensuring that ratepayers are protected from unexpected price increases.

These changes reflect Delaware's commitment to transitioning to clean energy sources and mitigating the impacts of climate change, particularly in a state that is highly vulnerable to sea-level rise【32†source】【33†source】【34†source】【35†source】.

For more detailed information about the RPS and its implications, you can visit the Delaware Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Control (DNREC) website.
